thread.title_full: Chelsea, West Ham supporters should find 'the right atmosphere' - Conte

author: Liam Twomey, Chelsea correspondent
title: Chelsea, West Ham supporters should find 'the right atmosphere' - Conte
text:
Chelsea, West Ham supporters should find 'the right atmosphere' - Conte Antonio Conte has denied any contact or negotiations to manage Inter Milan. 
LONDON -- Antonio Conte has urged Chelsea and West Ham supporters to focus on creating "the right atmosphere" when the two teams meet amid heavy security at the London Stadium on Monday. 
Violence erupted in the closing minutes of October's EFL Cup tie between the London rivals at the former Olympic venue with bottles, coins and chairs thrown and police intervention required inside the stadium, despite the presence of approximately 1,000 stewards. 
Seven arrests were made on the night and West Ham officials have since worked with Chelsea and Metropolitan Police to identify 97 supporters using CCTV footage and impose banning orders on them. 
Metropolitan Police insist there is an "appropriate, proportionate and robust" plan in place to prevent a repeat of the clashes, while West Ham have drawn up a "five-point plan" that involves giving stewards hand-held cameras to identify troublemakers and improved segregation of home and away supporters inside the stadium. Antonio Conte hopes there will be no repeat of the violence that marred the EFL Cup match between Chelsea and West Ham. 
"Last time wasn't good," Conte said. "I hope in this game our fans, the West Ham fans, enjoy totally the game and find the right atmosphere. In England, it's very strange for me to talk about this -- usually in every game you find the right atmosphere. 
"The last game against West Ham there was an exception. But I hope, on Monday, to find a good atmosphere in the stadium. I think the players, the club, the country deserves this." 
West Ham are one of only two teams to beat Chelsea since Conte's decision to switch to a 3-4-3 formation in late September, and he has primed his players for another difficult challenge as they bid to restore a 10-point lead at the top of the Premier League. 
"This game against West Ham, for us, is very important," he added. "In the last away game, the way we played against Burnley, we drew. They played very physical football against us. 
"Maybe it can happen, the same, against West Ham on Monday. But for this reason we are preparing for this type of situation. It will be a really tough game." 
Liam is ESPN FC's Chelsea correspondent. Follow him on Twitter: @Liam_Twomey.
